story.storybody:
The literary genius, Franz Kafka was born in a Jewish family and was the eldest of the six children. Franz died long before the World War II started and his two brothers and three sisters died in infancy and in the concentration camp, respectively, during World War II.

The author of well-received books like The Trial, The Castle and The Metamorphosis, Franz Kafka has been famous for inducing the feelings of absurdity and helplessness. He died of tuberculosis on June 3, 1924. It is said that the cause of his death was starvation because the condition of Kafka's throat made eating too painful for him.

{mosimage}
 

On his 92nd death anniversary, let's celebrate "the Dante of the 20th century" by knowing few lesser-known facts about his life:                          

1.   Kafka wrote a 100 page letter to his father explaining his authoritarian and demanding character. This letter is called as the "Letter to his Father".

2.   The dominating figure of Kafka's father had a significant influence on Kafka's writings.

3.   Despite his troubled relationship with his father, he lived with his parents until the age of 31.

4.   Kafka left his job at an Italian insurance company, because the working hours did not give him enough time to concentrate on his literary work.

{mosimage}
 

5.   Kafka wrote the story "The Judgment" in only one night.

6.   Writing was a form of prayer for Kafka.

7.   The poet Wystan Hugh Auden called Kafka the 'Dante of the twentieth century' and after reading Kafka's work, Gabriel Garcia Marquez noted that "it was possible to write in a different way".

8.   The writer never married but was engaged on three different occasions to two different women. He was engaged twice to the same woman, Felice Bauer, but they never married.

9.   In 1988, his handwritten manuscript of "The Trial" was sold for 1.98 million dollars.

10.  It is believed that Kafka wanted to commit suicide in late 1912.
